content.description:
From the guidebook: 

  Climb jugs to steep bulge. It may feel like cheating, but the routeÂ’s namesake no-hands rest   (basically a hanging, horizontal crevasse), enables one to de-pump (or take a nap) beforetackling the headwall bulge. There are two   headwall variations: a.) climb right of the   bolts for burlier action (5.11+), or b.) left of   the bolts for less so (5.11a).

climbs.name: Columbia
climbs.fa: FA - Kelley Chin in 2003  //  Bolted by Mark Hyde

content.description: From the guidebook:   Climb the route on the left side of the cave (denoted in fixed draws).  This POB classic was named in honor of the space shuttle Columbia, which broke apart in blue skies over the crag (north Texas) on January 1st, 2003.
From the guidebook:   Climb the blocky corner left of the cave.  Cool traversing moves.
content.location: Left most line outside of the Shuttle Cave.

content.description: Climb the first three bolts on Columbia and then move left and turn the lip and gain the ledge. From the ledge, move left and ascend the grey face using a cool pocket. Finish at the large tree that hangs over the wall and use this for an anchor.

From the guidebook:   (4 Routes from 5.9 to 5.12b, 3 boulder problems from V? to V? / Primarily South-facing) 

  The Shuttle Cave Area includes the walls & boulders left (upstream), and right (downstream) of the very obvious cave.  The cave is home to the rubbernecking line of Columbia (5.12b)
